eventName: Walking Around The World Step Challenge
story:
There’s some huge benefits for going out for a walk that we’ve all experienced over the last twelve months.

It’s not only about keeping active, it’s also about the mental break, the mood lifter the family-unifying power that it has.

What about those people that can’t go out to walk? Those people hit with some of the worse news of their lives whilst also dealing with the uncertainty of a world pandemic.

I’m talking about the roughly 367,000 people diagnosed with cancer last year…that’s around 1000 every day….and that’s just in the UK.

Whilst the whole world is suffering from the impact of the pandemic so too the whole world is struggling with the impact to support and care for those dealing with cancer.

That’s the reason why we’re going to be walking for MACMILLAN Cancer Support….not just the length of the UK.

WE’RE GOING TO BE WALKING THE GLOBE!

Over 12 weeks the U Fit Family are going to be walking the equivalent length of the whole world which equates to a total of 60,112,500 steps

Your contribution will make an impact, whether you donate £1 or £20. Every little bit helps

Thanks

The U Fit Family

pageSummaryWhat: Nitin Patani's family are all fundraising
story:
Nitin was a warm, smiling, and loving man who sadly passed away on the 13th of January 2021, after battling an unexpected diagnosis of myelodysplastic syndrome and leukaemia for the last 13 months. His strength of character always prevailed, as he fought with all his strength until the very end, whilst never letting his struggles show. 

It gives us great comfort that over these difficult months, Nitin was able to find encouragement within the Macmillan Cancer Support Charity, who provided him with endless and remarkable support on multiple levels. 

We have been so grateful for all the support, kind thoughts and gifts from all our friends and family over the last week; it has truly helped us through this hard time. We also know that Nitin would have wanted nothing more than for us to be able to give back to this wonderful charity, so thank you all for your generous and kind donations.

Lots of love, 
Raksha, Sajni, Bansi, Sonali & Nikhil

pageSummaryWhat: I'm doing 3miles per day for 30 days for Macmillan
story:
There are currently 3 million people living with cancer in the UK, and every 5 minutes, over 3 people in the UK are diagnosed with cancer

At a time where Macmillan’s support is needed more than ever by people living with cancer, they are also facing a significant drop in their income. The truth is that they can’t continue to be there for everyone who needs them without public donations.

We at Skiddle are doing what we can to raise the vital funds to help Macmillan be able to continue providing the same level of support to people who need it.

Skiddle have raised an impressive £295k for Macmillan so far and are close to reaching £300k!

And this is is why I am taking on a challenge to help us reach the £300k milestone, by running 3 miles per day for 30 consecutive days starting from Saturday 30th January and ending on Sunday 28th February.

The challenge isn't an easy one. It'll likely be extremely grim and facing the elements in the height of Winter won't be fun either. But that's exactly what's spurring me on and why I want to do this challenge over any other. Oh yes and not forgetting I haven't been regularly running for several months now 😂

I'll be posting regular updates on my Instagram at https://www.instagram.com/ellagreen960/

Wish me luck and donate what you can!

Big Loves 💚 xx

story: While we're all still in lockdown and the days are cold and short, it's so important we're still getting out and exercising... not just for our hearts and physical health but for our mental wellbeing too! This Heart Month, our team are committing to walk/jog/run 100km (60 miles) and we'd love to get as many people across the community to join in on the challenge too. 100km might sound a lot, but over a month it works out at roughly 2 miles a day - that's roughly a 20min jog, or a 30 minute walk. We're asking everyone who takes part to set a target of £100 and help spread the word. If we get 60 people to join the team, then that's £6,000 raised for the BHF's 60th year to go towards life-saving research. If 2020 taught us anything, it's that research works! Some companies have decided to sponsor employees taking part £1/km up to £100 - an incredible initiative to encourage employees to stay active and take breaks away from their desks. Be creative, feel free to put your own spin on the challenge and have fun! *The page will be live until the end of March (and, depending on uptake, into April) so if you want to take part in the challenge once the weather warms up, that's totally fine too!

story:
From BHF- The pandemic is the biggest challenge we've faced in our 60 year history. And it's led to us being forced to make the devastating decision to cut our 2020 research budget in half. Despite everything else happening at the moment, heart and circulatory diseases are still the world's biggest killers. For the sake of our mums and dads, brothers and sisters, grandparents and friends - we can't drop the ball now.

From me - In October 2019 my Papy was minutes away from Cardiac Arrest. With the amazing help of the NHS and the British Heart Foundation, he was given the operation he needed (6 stents to open up his artery!) and was home in no time. Without the British Heart Foundation and the NHS he may would not be with us today. I am truly grateful and would like to show my appreciation by raising money and doing my bit so others can have this same experience. Any donation is greatly appreciated and thankyou so much for taking the time to read my story. 

Emily x

story:
My family have lost so much due to heart disease. My Dad at 54, my uncle Robert at 41. Both my grandfathers had heart problems, my uncle Teddy suffered two heart attacks. There are probably more to add to the list. 

I lost my best friend, James at a young age to a massive heart attack as well as my Dad. I miss them both so much and I want to do something in their memory. I myself have also suffered a massive heart attack but I lived to tell the tale. Why? I don’t know. Maybe to raise awareness. 

So let’s raise some money so that we don’t lose anyone else that we love due to this awful disease.

pageSummaryWhat: I am not eating chocolate in march for dechox
story:
I want to raise money for the BHF and raise awareness of heart disease. My son was born with pulmonary atresia with ventricular septal defect, this meant he had no blood flow to his lungs once his ductus arteriosus closed after birth, he was put on medication instantly to keep this open and at 11 days old went to have a stent placed in that duct but it went wrong and the duct closed and his left lung detached itself, he had no blood flow to his lungs and he was rushed for emergency surgery, it was life or death, we were told to expect the worse because of his tiny little body going through such a major operation, the next day he has slightly improved so the doctors choose to take him off the ventilator, after coming off the ventilator he  showed he wasn't strong enough yet and he crashed right in front of us, he needed cpr, he was placed back on the ventilator and then his right lung collapsed, after a long 7 weeks in hospital after a bumpy recovery due to desats and randomly going blue! Before leaving the hospital we had to learn basic life support as he had a 10% chance of something going wrong until his repair. We finally came home for the first time with our baby boy! Still awaiting a full repair once he was bigger and stronger we stayed at home but we had to monitor his oxygen levels at home and he was on approximately 10 different medications 3 times a day, in and out of hospital with oxygen  levels in the 50-60s, Luca began to struggle, in December we got rushed to Southampton by blue lights after a week in Milton Keynes hospital on oxygen. Luca needed his repair he was so poorly, his left lung wasn't working when he was awake do was only using his Right lung to breathe when he was awake, Luca went for his repair but this didn't go as planned either, Luca seems to fall into the very small percentage of somthing going wrong, unfortunately due to the bypass machine that Luca needed for his surgery it caused a blood clot in his brain and several bleeds in his brain which meant Luca started acting neurological, along side this he had become addicted to morphine as he was on it intravenously for so long while on the ventilator, (he was on the ventilator about a week due to his heart working too hard after the operation. It was trying to do 2 rhythms at once so he had to have his heart 0aced with a pacing box). Now following that surgery Luca went into early stages of heart failure once we got home, so ended up back in Milton Keynes hospital, they've placed him on more medication to help and is now tube fed 90% of the time as he becomes very tired, I am hoping to raise money for research to help more babies like mine keep fighting to get better.


Please veiw Luca's gallery to see the gorgeous little boy that makes everyone smile x

pageSummaryWhat: Giving up chocolate, sweets, and fizzy drinks
story: When my mum was in her first year of university, her dad died of a huge heart attack, which caused devastation in her side of the family. Her sister was only 16.  No family should have to go through that, so I’m dechoxing again this year in his memory. It feels even more significant this year, because I’m the age now that my mum was when she lost her dad. I can’t imagine losing one of my parents yet! With the pandemic money is hard to come by, so anything you can give would mean the world to me. This cause matters so much to me, so I’m giving up all chocolate, sweets, and fizzy drinks throughout March!! (If you know me you’ll know I love jelly sweets more than anything so this isn’t gonna be easy!!) but I’m hoping it will help improve my health and boost my weight loss too! If the money I raise can help just one family not to go through what my mum’s family went through, it’ll be so worth it. So please give what you can, and share this with as many people as possible, it really does mean the world to me

story:
The Tommy Godwin Challenge cycling event started in 2013 to raise essential funds for Marie Curie West Midlands.

Tommy was a local cycling hero who won two bronze medals in the 1948 Olympics, as well as many awards at National and Commonwealth levels. He went on to be the Team Manager for the GB cycling team at the 1964 Olympics in Japan. As well as running his bike shop in Kings Heath he contributed greatly to sporting legacy in the West Midlands.

He passed away in 2012, spending his last few weeks at the Marie Curie Hospice.

The event has continued to grow and thus far has a raised in excess of £120,000 for the Hospice.


It costs over £11,300 per day to keep the Hospice running, so every penny we raise DOES make a difference. Our challenge for 2021 is to raise enough money to run the hospice for a day.

Further information available from our website at:-

https://www.tommygodwinchallenge.org

The Marie Curie Solihull Hospice has been caring for local people since 1965.Its a warm and welcoming place where we give expert care to people with a terminal illness, and their loved ones, every day of the year. Our hospice team includes doctors, nurses, physiotherapists, social workers and many more, and is supported by over 200 volunteers who play a vital role in the running of the hospice.We have a 24-bed in-patient unit, where relatives and friends can visit any time of the day or night, and stay with their loved ones if they wish.Our out-patient unit offers clinics, therapies and group sessions and freshly cooked lunches made by our chefs. We also support carers and families, including children, with practical advice, counselling and bereavement support groups. Thank you for helping to make sure more people with a terminal illness in Solihull get the care and support they need.

We'll be here for you and your family when you may feel like no-one else is, to help you cope when you don't know how. Marie Curie Nurses care for you in your home, when you need them most, day or night. Our hospices are at the heart of communities around the UK. And our trained volunteers and advisers are here for you with practical information and support when you don't know what to do next or just need to talk. 
We'll be by your side with care and support every step of the way, bringing light in the darkest hours.

pageSummaryWhat: Evelyn has decided to do a 24hr silence
story:
During lockdown Evelyn (age 9) has been reading 'National Geographic' kids and it has raised her awareness of endangered animals. She has decided to do something to raise money to help protect animals at risk of extinction.

She is an animal lover, and hopes to be a vet or work for the RSPCA when she grows up. Her favourite animals are the red panda and white tiger. Evelyn says:

"I want to raise money because our animals might go extinct. We need to stop killing animals for their fur. Animals are very important because without them we wouldn't have fertilizer, which would affect our plants and oxygen supply. Once an animal goes extinct it won't be around ever again. We need to try and help raise awareness"

Were doing everything we can to protect the poorest people from coronavirus. But we need your help to do more.

Your support helps us deliver soap, clean water and sanitation services such as handwashing facilities to keep more families safe.

Its a difficult time for everyone  but anything you can do to support can make a difference and save lives. Thank you.

story: I am fundraising because Unicef urgently need funds to expand the scale and scope of their work supporting children affected by coronavirus, especially in countries with weaker health systems. Just £30 could provide a full kit to protect a health-worker on the frontline, including gloves, masks and coveralls, while just £43 could help provide 1,680 pairs of disposable gloves for health workers. The impact of a large-scale outbreak of coronavirus on children, especially poor and vulnerable children, has been immense. Children are at risk from the disease, but also from the disruption to health and education services, impacts on caregivers, and separation from family members. Unicef has been working closely with governments and the World Health Organization (WHO) since the start of the coronavirus outbreak. Donations made to my page will help to limit the spread of the virus and reduce the impact on children and families.

story:
In memory of Navin C. Modi

We are saddened to annouce the passing of Navin Modi, aged 77, of Twickenham, London. Who passed away on Saturday 9th January 2021. 

Navin, was originally from Navsari, India and migrated as a teenager to London, England in 1961 where he would support his parents and eventually rasie his very own family. 

Navin is survived by his wife Vasanti, his two children Paresh and Yogesh, daughter-in -law Anjana and his beloved grandchildren Ava and Xavier.

An inspirational and positive person, Dad never failed to put a lasting smile on the faces of the people he met. 

Donations
